keyFeatures.title: Key Features
keyFeatures.subtitle: Every feature exists to eliminate the gap between field work and payroll processing.

feature1.title: Pay Period Configuration
feature1.description: Choose weekly, bi-weekly, semi-monthly, or monthly pay periods. The system auto-generates period boundaries. Work sessions group into the correct pay period automatically.

feature2.title: GPS-Verified Time Data

feature3.title: Configurable Overtime Rules

feature4.title: Project Attribution

feature5.title: Billable vs Non-Billable Tracking
feature5.description: Distinguish revenue-generating client hours from operational costs. Travel, equipment maintenance, training, weather delays. Know your true labor cost.

feature6.title: Export Capabilities
feature6.description: CSV export for payroll software integration (QuickBooks, ADP, Gusto). PDF timesheet reports for records. Employee-level detail and project cost breakdowns available.

faqs.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faqs.subtitle: Common questions about the Payroll & Financial module.

faq1.question: Does OnRopePro calculate my taxes and deductions?
faq1.answer: No. OnRopePro prepares payroll-ready timesheet data for export. Actual payroll calculations (CPP, EI, tax withholding, Social Security, Medicare) happen in your payroll processing software (QuickBooks, ADP, Gusto, etc.). OnRopePro handles time aggregation and export, not tax compliance.

faq2.question: What pay period options are available?
faq2.answer: Weekly, bi-weekly, semi-monthly, and monthly. The system generates period boundaries automatically based on your selection.

faq3.question: How does overtime calculation work?
faq3.answer: You configure the rules: daily trigger (default 8 hours), weekly trigger (default 40 hours), and multiplier (1.5x, 2x, etc.). The system applies these rules automatically to every work session. You can disable overtime entirely if your pay structure doesn't include it.

faq4.question: What format does the export use?
faq4.answer: CSV for payroll software import. PDF for printable timesheet records. Both include employee-level detail and project attribution.

faq5.question: Who can see payroll data?
faq5.answer: Users with the canAccessFinancials permission. This is granted through the role-based permission system. Technicians see their own hours but not compensation rates or other employees' data.

faq6.question: What happens if a work session is missing or incorrect?
faq6.answer: Supervisors with appropriate permissions can review and adjust work sessions before timesheet approval. All adjustments are logged with reasons for audit purposes.

faq7.question: Can I see historical pay periods?
faq7.answer: Yes. Previous pay periods remain accessible. Filter by date range to pull data from any past period.

faq8.question: Does project attribution work if a technician works at multiple buildings in one day?
faq8.answer: Yes. Each work session links to a specific project. If a technician clocks into Building A for 4 hours, then Building B for 4 hours, both sessions show separately with their respective project attribution.

faq9.question: What about non-billable time like travel between sites?
faq9.answer: Non-billable work sessions track hours that cannot be charged to clients (travel, training, equipment maintenance, weather delays). The payroll view shows both billable and non-billable hours so you know your true labor cost.

faq10.question: Is there an approval workflow before export?
faq10.answer: Yes. Timesheets can be reviewed and approved before export. Approved timesheets generate clean export files. The workflow prevents exporting data that hasn't been verified.

hero.title: When the Auditor Shows Up,
hero.subtitle: Will You Be Scrambling or Ready?
hero.description: Every document. Every signature. Every timestamp. Searchable in seconds, not scattered across filing cabinets.
hero.descriptionStrong: Build compliance records that protect your business when it matters most.

problem.title: The Compliance Gap Nobody Talks About
problem.intro: You handed your new hire the safety manual. He said "yep, I read it" and set it aside.
problem.scenario: Two weeks later, he causes damage during a window cleaning job because he used a technique from his old company. Now you're facing a claim, and "he told me he read it" is your entire defense.
problem.reality: Paper systems don't fail during normal operations. They fail during audits, lawsuits, and insurance investigations. The moment you need to prove compliance, you discover scattered files, missing signatures, and no way to verify who actually reviewed what.
problem.solution: OnRopePro treats document management as the foundation of your liability protection. Every acknowledgment is timestamped. Every signature is permanent. When WorkSafeBC asks for proof, you don't search. You generate a report.

features.title: What This Module Does
features.subtitle: Your complete document compliance infrastructure. Centralizes every safety manual, policy, procedure, and certificate with digital signatures that create defensible compliance records.

signature.title: Digital Signature Capture
signature.description: When employees review documents, they sign digitally with a captured timestamp. No more "I didn't know" excuses. The signature proves they saw the exact version you uploaded, on the exact date and time.

compliance.title: Compliance Status Tracking
compliance.description: See exactly who has signed which documents, who has gaps, and who needs reminders. Dashboards show missing acknowledgments before they become audit findings.

audit.title: Instant Audit Response
audit.description: Generate compliance reports in seconds. When regulators, insurers, or attorneys ask for documentation, you provide professional reports instead of paper shuffling.

stakeholders.title: Who Benefits From This Module
stakeholders.subtitle: Every stakeholder gets the document access and compliance visibility they need.

liability.title: Liability protection that stands up in court.
liability.description: Every signed document creates a permanent record with employee name, timestamp, and version. When accidents happen, you prove due diligence instead of scrambling for evidence.

insurance.title: Insurance compliance without the panic.
insurance.description: Upload your Certificate of Insurance with expiration tracking. The system warns you before renewal deadlines so you never lose work from lapsed coverage.

history.title: Complete business history, accessible anywhere.
history.description: Your safety procedures, policy changes, and training records become searchable institutional memory. Even when employees leave, compliance history stays.

procedures.title: Know exactly what procedures apply to you.
procedures.description: No more guessing whether you're following the right version. Your document list shows what requires your signature and what you've already acknowledged.

record.title: Your compliance record travels with you.
record.description: Every document you sign becomes part of your professional history. When you move between employers within OnRopePro, your acknowledgments demonstrate your commitment to safety culture.

simple.title: Simple, clear process.
simple.description: Review the document, sign digitally, and you're done. No paper forms, no chasing supervisors for signature sheets.

confidence.title: Confidence in contractor safety culture.
confidence.description: You can see a contractor's Company Safety Rating (CSR), which reflects document acknowledgment rates among their employees. High CSR means consistent safety engagement.

protection.title: Protection for your property.
protection.description: When contractors have verified training records and policy acknowledgments, you reduce your liability exposure from work performed at your building.

vendor.title: Vendor qualification at a glance.
vendor.description: CSR scores tell you which rope access contractors maintain active safety cultures versus those running on paper and assumptions.

diligence.title: Simplified due diligence.
diligence.description: Instead of requesting individual documents, you can verify safety compliance through a single rating that aggregates employee acknowledgment data.

safety.title: Work happens safely at your building.
safety.description: The contractors working outside your window have verified training records and acknowledged safety procedures. That's how professional operations work.

keyFeatures.title: Key Features
keyFeatures.subtitle: Every feature is built to create defensible compliance records that protect your business.

immutableAudit.title: Immutable Audit Trail
immutableAudit.description: Once signed, signature records cannot be deleted or modified. This creates permanent, tamper-proof compliance documentation for regulators, insurers, and legal defense.

swpTemplates.title: 15 Pre-Built SWP Templates

safetyTopics.title: 10 Daily Safety Practice Topics
safetyTopics.description: Rotating safety discussion topics with employee acknowledgment tracking. Regular engagement demonstrates active safety culture and contributes to your CSR score.

expirationTracking.title: Expiration Tracking
expirationTracking.description: Upload insurance certificates with expiration dates. The system provides advance warnings so you never get caught with lapsed coverage during a client request.

roleBasedAccess.title: Role-Based Access

csrIntegration.title: CSR Integration

problemsSolved.title: Problems Solved
problemsSolved.subtitle: Real problems. Real solutions. Organized by who you are.

problem1.title: "Employees Don't Actually Read Safety Documents"
problem1.description: You hand an employee your company safety manual and tell them to read it. They take it, set it aside, and say "yep, I read it" without ever opening it. They just want to get on the ropes and start working. Now you have zero proof they understood your procedures, and if something goes wrong, their ignorance becomes your liability.
problem1.solution: Digital signature capture requires employees to actively acknowledge each document. The system records who signed, when they signed, and which specific document version they reviewed. Employees cannot claim ignorance when their signature is timestamped in the system.

problem2.title: "Scrambling for Documents During WorkSafeBC Audits"
problem2.description: WorkSafeBC shows up for an audit and you're scrambling. Paper files are scattered across filing cabinets, desk drawers, and maybe a folder on someone's computer. You have no idea who signed what, who saw what, when they saw it, or whether they saw it at all. The auditor is waiting while your operations manager digs through boxes.
problem2.solution: Centralized document storage with instant compliance reports. Every document, signature, and acknowledgment is searchable. Generate a complete compliance report showing all employee signatures in seconds, not hours.

problem3.title: "Nobody Knows If Insurance Is Current"
problem3.description: Your Certificate of Insurance is filed somewhere, but nobody remembers when it expires. You find out it lapsed when a building manager asks for current documentation, forcing you to scramble for a renewal that may take days. Meanwhile, you cannot legally work on that property.
problem3.solution: Upload insurance certificates with expiration date tracking. The system provides advance warnings before expiry so you can renew proactively. Restricted visibility ensures only authorized personnel access sensitive financial documents.

problem1.title: "Some Employees Know Procedures, Some Don't, Some Think They Know"
problem1.description: You have 15 technicians on payroll. Some have worked with you for years and know every procedure. faqs.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faqs.subtitle: Common questions about document management and compliance.

faq1.question: Can I edit or delete a signed document acknowledgment?
faq1.answer: No. Once a document acknowledgment is signed, the signature record is permanent and cannot be modified or deleted. This creates an immutable audit trail that protects both employers and employees. Regulators require tamper-proof documentation to verify compliance.

faq2.question: What happens when I update a document?
faq2.answer: When you upload a new version, the system creates a new document that requires fresh acknowledgments from all employees. Previous signatures remain associated with the previous version. This ensures employees always acknowledge the current procedure, not an outdated version.

faq3.question: Who can see my Certificate of Insurance?
faq3.answer: Only Company Owner and Ops Manager roles can view COI documents. Supervisors and Technicians cannot access these restricted financial documents. Insurance certificates contain sensitive financial information that should be limited to authorized personnel.

faq4.question: How do Safe Work Practices affect my CSR?
faq4.answer: Employee acknowledgment of daily safety practice topics contributes positively to your Company Safety Rating. Consistent engagement demonstrates an active safety culture. CSR rewards companies that don't just have safety documents but actively engage employees with safety topics.

faq5.question: Can building managers see my documents?
faq5.answer: Building managers cannot see your actual documents. They can see your CSR score, which reflects your overall safety compliance including document acknowledgment rates. This protects your proprietary procedures while giving building managers confidence in your safety practices.

faq6.question: What file types are supported?
faq6.answer: PDF, DOC, and DOCX files are supported for document uploads. File type validation ensures only appropriate formats are accepted.

faq7.question: What happens if an employee leaves?
faq7.answer: Their signature history remains in the system permanently. This maintains your audit trail even after employment ends. You can still prove that a former employee acknowledged specific procedures during their tenure.

faq8.question: How does this integrate with onboarding?
faq8.answer: New employees see all required documents highlighted for acknowledgment. Onboarding checklists can include document acknowledgment milestones. New hires cannot claim they missed required procedures because the system tracks completion status.

faq9.question: Can employees sign from mobile devices?
faq9.answer: Yes. Document review and digital signature capture work from any device. Technicians can acknowledge procedures from the field without returning to the office.

faq10.question: What's included in compliance reports?
faq10.answer: Reports show employee signature status by document, acknowledgment timestamps, missing signature alerts, and complete version history. Export as PDF for professional audit presentation or CSV for data analysis.

faqs.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faqs.subtitle: Everything you need to know about the Company Safety Rating.
faqs.q1: How is the starting score calculated?
faqs.a1: New companies start at 75%. Upload your Certificate of Insurance, Health & Safety Manual, and Company Policy to reach 100%. From there, penalties are applied based on ongoing compliance gaps.
faqs.q2: What if I add Safe Work Procedures and my score drops?
faqs.a2: This is intentional. When you add new safety documents, your score temporarily decreases until employees review and sign them. This ensures documents aren't just uploaded and forgotten. Once all employees acknowledge the new procedures, your score returns to full compliance.
faqs.q3: How do harness inspection penalties work?
faqs.a3: The penalty is calculated as a percentage of missed inspections against total work sessions. If you have 1,000 work sessions and miss 10 inspections, that's a 1% penalty. If you're just starting and have 10 sessions with 5 missed inspections, that's a 50% penalty in this category. Consistent compliance over time builds a resilient score.
faqs.q4: Can technicians see my CSR before accepting job offers?
faqs.a4: Yes. Technicians evaluating potential employers can see company CSR ratings. This allows them to make informed decisions about safety before committing to a position.
faqs.a5: Property managers see your overall CSR percentage and a color-coded badge (green, yellow, orange, or red) through their vendor dashboard. They can also see category breakdowns but not your internal operational details.
faqs.a6: Building managers and residents. Building managers handle on-site logistics (keys, water, parking) and don't make vendor selection decisions. Residents seeing safety scores would generate unnecessary concerns without appropriate context.
faqs.q7: What documents are required for each project?
faqs.a7: Four documents: Anchor Inspection (waived for non-rope jobs like parkade pressure washing), Rope Access Plan, Toolbox Meeting, and FLHA. Missing any of these for a project contributes to your project documents penalty.
faqs.q8: Can my score ever reach 100% again after adding employees or documents?
faqs.a8: Yes. 100% is achievable when all company documents are current, all projects have complete documentation, all work sessions have associated harness inspections, and all employees have signed all required documents. The system is designed so perfect scores are difficult to maintain long-term, reflecting that nobody is 100% safe forever.
faqs.q9: How quickly does the score update?
faqs.a9: Real-time. When a technician completes a harness inspection, when an employee signs a document, when a toolbox meeting is logged, the score recalculates immediately.
faqs.q10: What if a new employee joins and hasn't signed anything yet?
faqs.a10: Your score will decrease proportionally until they complete onboarding documentation. This incentivizes prompt completion of new employee safety training and document acknowledgments.
faqs.q11: Can I export CSR data for insurance or regulatory purposes?
faqs.a11: Yes. Generate PDF reports showing employee signatures with timestamps for all safety documents, harness inspection completion records, and toolbox meeting logs. These exports satisfy insurance auditors, WorkSafe inspectors, and IRATA/SPRAT compliance requirements.
faqs.q12: Is the CSR visible to competitors?
faqs.a12: No. Only your own company owners, your technicians (when evaluating job offers), and property managers (when viewing their vendor list) can see your score. Competitors cannot access your CSR.

q1.question: What if I have 10 harnesses but only registered 5 serial numbers?
q1.answer1: You still have 10 available slots. Serial numbers are optional metadata, not gatekeepers. The slot-based model counts quantity, not serial registrations.
q1.answer2: Add serials gradually as equipment is distributed.

q2.question: Can two different items have the same serial number?
q2.answer1: Yes. Serial numbers must be unique within each gear item type, but a harness and a rope can both have serial "HR-001." Different manufacturers use similar numbering schemes.
q2.answer2: The system prevents duplicates within an item type, which is what matters for tracking.

q3.question: What happens when equipment expires?
q3.answer1: The system tracks in-service dates with color-coded indicators for review. Hard gear (5 years) and soft gear (10 years) guidelines are displayed.
q3.answer2: You decide when to retire based on inspections and manufacturer recommendations. OnRopePro provides data for decision-making; actual retirement decisions should involve qualified safety professionals.

q4.question: Who can see equipment prices?
q4.answer1: Only users with financial permissions. Regular employees see quantities and assignments but not dollar values.
q4.answer2: Financial data is sensitive. Owners need it for budgeting and insurance. Employees don't need to know what their harness cost.

q5.question: Can I delete a serial number that's assigned to someone?
q5.answer1: No. Return the gear assignment first, then delete or edit the serial. This prevents orphaned assignments pointing to non-existent serials.
q5.answer2: Data integrity is maintained by enforcing proper return workflow.

q6.question: What if I need to reduce quantity below what's assigned?
q6.answer1: You cannot. If 5 items are assigned, you cannot reduce quantity below 5. Return some assignments first.
q6.answer2: This prevents negative availability and ensures the system always reflects physical reality.

q7.question: Do employees need permission to assign gear to themselves?
q7.answer1: No. All employees can self-assign from available inventory and remove their own assignments. No special permission required.
q7.answer2: This reduces administrative burden while maintaining complete tracking.

q8.question: How does equipment get added to inventory?
q8.answer1: Navigate to inventory, add item, select equipment type, pick brand and model from pre-loaded database, enter quantity.
q8.answer2: Optionally add serial numbers and assign to employees during the same workflow. One-time setup, then the system maintains itself.

q9.question: What's the difference between 'Manage Inventory' and 'Assign Gear' permissions?
q9.answer1: Manage Inventory allows adding new gear items, editing quantities, and registering serial numbers. Assign Gear allows distributing equipment to other employees.
q9.answer2: Owners have both. Supervisors might have Assign Gear without Manage Inventory, depending on your workflow.

q10.question: Can employees see what gear coworkers have?
q10.answer1: Only with View Team Gear permission. Otherwise, employees see only their own kit.
q10.answer2: Owners and supervisors typically have Team Gear visibility. Regular techs typically don't.

faq1.question: Does white-label branding affect any module functionality?
faq1.answer: No. Branding changes only visual elements (logos, colors, PDF headers). All OnRopePro capabilities, workflows, and integrations function identically regardless of branding status. Your team's operational processes remain unchanged.

faq2.question: Can I preview branding changes before applying them to the live platform?
faq2.answer: Not currently. Logo uploads and color selections apply immediately platform-wide. Best practice: Update branding during off-peak hours (evenings, weekends) when fewer employees and clients actively use the system. Most companies finalize branding within 2-3 adjustment attempts.

faq3.question: What happens to our branding if our subscription expires?
faq3.answer: The system automatically reverts to OnRopePro default branding immediately upon subscription expiration. You receive three warning notifications (30 days, 7 days, 1 day before expiration) to prevent surprise changes. Reactivate your subscription to restore branded experience instantly.

faq4.question: Will clients know we're using OnRopePro?
faq4.answer: Client-facing elements display only your branding. OnRopePro attribution appears only in footer copyright notices (industry standard for white-label platforms). Building managers, property managers, and residents interact exclusively with your branded experience throughout portals, notifications, and documentation.

faq5.question: Can we use custom domain names like portal.ourcompany.com?
faq5.answer: Not currently. Custom domain mapping is not included in current White Label Branding. All access remains through onropepro.com URLs regardless of branding status. This may be added in future versions based on customer demand.

faq6.question: How long does it take to set up white-label branding?
faq6.answer: Complete setup requires under 10 minutes: subscribe to Professional plan or higher (2 minutes), upload company logo (1 minute), select two brand colors (2 minutes), verify appearance across sample interfaces (5 minutes). Branding activates instantly after configuration.

faq7.question: What file formats do you support for logo uploads?
faq7.answer: PNG and JPG formats only. Recommended dimensions: 300x100 pixels minimum for clear display across headers and mobile interfaces. Maximum file size: 2MB. The system rejects uploads that don't meet format or size requirements.

faq8.question: Can we change our branding after it's set up?
faq8.answer: Yes. Access the Branding tab in Profile settings anytime to upload new logos or adjust brand colors. Changes propagate instantly platform-wide with no waiting period or approval required. Update frequency is unlimited for active subscribers.

faq9.question: Does white-label branding work on mobile devices?
faq9.answer: Yes. Logo and brand colors display across all device types: desktop browsers, tablets, and smartphones. When users add OnRopePro to their mobile home screens, the app icon displays your company logo instead of generic OnRopePro branding. Full branded experience across every device.

faq10.question: What if our company rebrands with new colors or logo?
faq10.answer: Update your branding through the Profile, Branding tab. Upload your new logo and select updated brand colors. Changes apply instantly across the entire platform, all employee accounts, and all client-facing portals. No technical support needed. No downtime. No additional fees.

faq11.question: Can multiple people in our company manage branding settings?
faq11.answer: Only users with Owner or Admin permissions can access branding settings. This permission restriction prevents unauthorized branding changes by project supervisors or technicians. Grant Admin permissions to your operations manager or marketing team member if you want them to manage branding independently.

faq12.question: Is there a limit to how many times we can change our branding?
faq12.answer: No limits. Update logos and colors as frequently as needed at no additional cost. Most companies update branding once during initial setup and rarely change it afterward unless they rebrand the company. Seasonal color adjustments (holiday themes, awareness campaigns) are supported if desired.

faqs.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faqs.subtitle: Common questions about the Payroll & Financial module.

faq1.question: Does OnRopePro calculate my taxes and deductions?
faq1.answer: No. OnRopePro prepares payroll-ready timesheet data for export. Actual payroll calculations (CPP, EI, tax withholding, Social Security, Medicare) happen in your payroll processing software (QuickBooks, ADP, Gusto, etc.). OnRopePro handles time aggregation and export, not tax compliance.

faq2.question: What pay period options are available?
faq2.answer: Weekly, bi-weekly, semi-monthly, and monthly. The system generates period boundaries automatically based on your selection.

faq3.question: How does overtime calculation work?
faq3.answer: You configure the rules: daily trigger (default 8 hours), weekly trigger (default 40 hours), and multiplier (1.5x, 2x, etc.). The system applies these rules automatically to every work session. You can disable overtime entirely if your pay structure doesn't include it.

faq4.question: What format does the export use?
faq4.answer: CSV for payroll software import. PDF for printable timesheet records. Both include employee-level detail and project attribution.

faq5.question: Who can see payroll data?
faq5.answer: Users with the canAccessFinancials permission. This is granted through the role-based permission system. Technicians see their own hours but not compensation rates or other employees' data.

faq6.question: What happens if a work session is missing or incorrect?
faq6.answer: Supervisors with appropriate permissions can review and adjust work sessions before timesheet approval. All adjustments are logged with reasons for audit purposes.

faq7.question: Can I see historical pay periods?
faq7.answer: Yes. Previous pay periods remain accessible. Filter by date range to pull data from any past period.

faq8.question: Does project attribution work if a technician works at multiple buildings in one day?
faq8.answer: Yes. Each work session links to a specific project. If a technician clocks into Building A for 4 hours, then Building B for 4 hours, both sessions show separately with their respective project attribution.

faq9.question: What about non-billable time like travel between sites?
faq9.answer: Non-billable work sessions track hours that cannot be charged to clients (travel, training, equipment maintenance, weather delays). The payroll view shows both billable and non-billable hours so you know your true labor cost.

faq10.question: Is there an approval workflow before export?
faq10.answer: Yes. Timesheets can be reviewed and approved before export. Approved timesheets generate clean export files. The workflow prevents exporting data that hasn't been verified.

q1.question: Can technicians login with their IRATA number instead of email?

q3.question: Are role permissions predefined or do I have to set them up?
q3.answer: All roles except Company Owner start with zero permissions. You must explicitly grant each permission the employee needs. This prevents accidental over-permission and allows precise matching of access to job requirements and trust level.

q4.question: Does the system alert for driver's license expiration too?
q4.answer: Yes. Driver's license expiration dates are tracked and included in the same alert system as IRATA/SPRAT certifications. Visual indicators and notifications function identically.

q5.question: What happens to data when an employee is terminated?
q5.answer: The employee loses system access immediately, but all historical data is preserved. Work sessions, safety documents, equipment assignments, and payroll history remain in the system for compliance and audit purposes. This is a soft delete, not a hard delete.

q6.question: Can I use this for employees who aren't rope access technicians?
q6.answer: Yes. While certification tracking is designed for rope access (IRATA/SPRAT), the module supports roles like Labourer, Ground Crew, and general support staff who may not have rope access certifications. Leave certification fields empty for non-certified staff.

q7.answer: Modify their permissions immediately. Remove financial access, hide client information, restrict to basic functions. No formal demotion required. Changes take effect instantly. Access modifications are logged for potential legal proceedings.

q8.question: Can employees see each other's pay rates?
q8.answer: Only if you grant them that specific permission. Financial visibility is separated from operational access. Your supervisor can create projects and check budgets without seeing what every technician earns.

q9.answer: IRATA level and expiration, SPRAT certification, driver's license validity, and First Aid certification. All display visual status indicators (green/amber/red) and trigger 30-day warning alerts before expiration.

faq1.question: Does this replace my physical IRATA/SPRAT logbook?
faq1.answer: No. IRATA and SPRAT still require physical logbooks. WorkSafeBC and other regulatory bodies may request to see your written records on-site. OnRopePro is a digital supplement that helps you maintain accurate records, never lose your hour history, and have a reliable backup for your paper logbook.

faq2.question: What happens to my hours if I change employers?
faq2.answer: Your IRATA/SPRAT hours belong to your technician profile, not your employer. When you move to a new company, your complete hour history comes with you automatically. No re-entry required.

faq3.question: Can I log hours if I'm not connected to an employer on the platform?
faq3.answer: Yes. Independent technicians can manually log their hours and tasks. You can also scan your existing paper logbook to import historical data.

faq4.question: How do I log training hours from external courses?
faq4.answer: Training at IRATA/SPRAT schools counts as rope time. Use the manual entry feature to add training hours, specifying the training provider and skills practiced.

faq5.question: What's the difference between shift hours and task hours?
faq5.answer: Shift hours are your total time at work. Task hours are the actual time performing rope access activities. An 8-hour shift might only include 6-7 hours of actual rope work after breaks, travel, and ground prep. The system prompts you to specify how many of your shift hours were actual task hours.

faq6.question: What if my employer doesn't use OnRopePro?
faq6.answer: You can still create a technician account and log hours manually. When your employer eventually joins the platform (or you move to an employer who uses it), your existing hour history integrates automatically.

faq7.question: Can Level 3s approve hours digitally?
faq7.answer: Digital signature and approval flow is planned for future release (pending us contacting IRATA and SPRAT). Currently, hours log to your profile without supervisor sign-off. Once IRATA formally approves digital logging, the approval workflow will activate.

faq8.question: What if I have no logged rope time for 6 months?
faq8.answer: IRATA may consider your certification invalid until recertification if you have no logged rope time for 6 months. Consistent logging through OnRopePro ensures you never have unexplained gaps that could jeopardize your credentials.

faq9.question: Is this a Plus feature or standard?
faq9.answer: Logbook scanning and basic hour logging are available to all technician accounts. Certification progress tracking (hours remaining to next level) requires Plus.

faqs.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faqs.subtitle: Everything you need to know about the Company Safety Rating.
faqs.q1: How is the starting score calculated?
faqs.a1: New companies start at 75%. Upload your Certificate of Insurance, Health & Safety Manual, and Company Policy to reach 100%. From there, penalties are applied based on ongoing compliance gaps.
faqs.q2: What if I add Safe Work Procedures and my score drops?
faqs.a2: This is intentional. When you add new safety documents, your score temporarily decreases until employees review and sign them. This ensures documents aren't just uploaded and forgotten. Once all employees acknowledge the new procedures, your score returns to full compliance.
faqs.q3: How do harness inspection penalties work?
faqs.a3: The penalty is calculated as a percentage of missed inspections against total work sessions. If you have 1,000 work sessions and miss 10 inspections, that's a 1% penalty. If you're just starting and have 10 sessions with 5 missed inspections, that's a 50% penalty in this category. Consistent compliance over time builds a resilient score.
faqs.q4: Can technicians see my CSR before accepting job offers?
faqs.a4: Yes. Technicians evaluating potential employers can see company CSR ratings. This allows them to make informed decisions about safety before committing to a position.
faqs.a5: Property managers see your overall CSR percentage and a color-coded badge (green, yellow, orange, or red) through their vendor dashboard. They can also see category breakdowns but not your internal operational details.
faqs.a6: Building managers and residents. Building managers handle on-site logistics (keys, water, parking) and don't make vendor selection decisions. Residents seeing safety scores would generate unnecessary concerns without appropriate context.
faqs.q7: What documents are required for each project?
faqs.a7: Four documents: Anchor Inspection (waived for non-rope jobs like parkade pressure washing), Rope Access Plan, Toolbox Meeting, and FLHA. Missing any of these for a project contributes to your project documents penalty.
faqs.q8: Can my score ever reach 100% again after adding employees or documents?
faqs.a8: Yes. 100% is achievable when all company documents are current, all projects have complete documentation, all work sessions have associated harness inspections, and all employees have signed all required documents. The system is designed so perfect scores are difficult to maintain long-term, reflecting that nobody is 100% safe forever.
faqs.q9: How quickly does the score update?
faqs.a9: Real-time. When a technician completes a harness inspection, when an employee signs a document, when a toolbox meeting is logged, the score recalculates immediately.
faqs.q10: What if a new employee joins and hasn't signed anything yet?
faqs.a10: Your score will decrease proportionally until they complete onboarding documentation. This incentivizes prompt completion of new employee safety training and document acknowledgments.
faqs.q11: Can I export CSR data for insurance or regulatory purposes?
faqs.a11: Yes. Generate PDF reports showing employee signatures with timestamps for all safety documents, harness inspection completion records, and toolbox meeting logs. These exports satisfy insurance auditors, WorkSafe inspectors, and IRATA/SPRAT compliance requirements.
faqs.q12: Is the CSR visible to competitors?
faqs.a12: No. Only your own company owners, your technicians (when evaluating job offers), and property managers (when viewing their vendor list) can see your score. Competitors cannot access your CSR.

faqs.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faqs.subtitle: Common questions about the Resident Portal.

q1.question: Can residents see other residents' complaints?
q1.answer: No. Residents can only view and interact with their own feedback submissions. Privacy is protected by design.

q2.question: What happens when a resident moves to a different building?
q2.answer: They update their Strata/LMS number in their profile and enter the new vendor's code. Their account is fully portable. If the new building's vendor uses OnRopePro, they see that vendor's projects. If not, they notice the gap.

q3.question: Can residents reopen closed feedback?
q3.answer: No. Only company staff can reopen closed feedback. If a resident believes the issue persists, they contact their property manager or building manager directly. This prevents endless back-and-forth on resolved issues.

q4.question: Can property managers respond to resident feedback?
q4.answer: No. Property managers can view all feedback and communication history but cannot respond. Only company staff communicate with residents through the system. This keeps property managers informed without requiring their involvement.

q5.question: What's the difference between internal notes and visible replies?
q5.answer: Internal notes are private (staff only) for coordination, investigation findings, and sensitive discussions. Visible replies are seen by the resident for acknowledgment, status updates, and resolution communication. Staff must explicitly toggle a yellow/red checkbox to make a reply visible, preventing accidental exposure.

q6.question: How do residents get the vendor code?
q6.answer: The code is posted on notices in the elevator during projects, provided by the building manager, or included in project communications. One code per company, used for all buildings that company services.

q7.question: Is there one code per building or one code per company?
q7.answer: One code per company. All residents across all buildings serviced by that company use the same vendor code. The Strata/LMS number differentiates which building's projects they see.

q8.question: How long do residents have to submit feedback after a project completes?
q8.answer: 5 business days. This allows time for residents to notice issues while limiting the complaint window to a reasonable period.

q9.question: What happens if feedback sits unread?
q9.answer: Notification badges show pending items in your dashboard. The "Viewed" timestamp is visible to the resident, so they know if no one has opened their feedback. This creates natural accountability.

q10.question: Do residents see when we add internal notes?
q10.answer: No. Internal notes are completely invisible to residents. They only see visible replies and status changes.

faq1.question: What if a tech doesn't have an OnRopePro Passport?
faq1.answer: You can still add them as an employee the traditional way. But you'll collect their information manually, verify certifications yourself, and chase safety acknowledgments via email. The value of Passports is that everything is already done.

faq2.question: How do techs get Passports?

Encourage your current techs to create Passports. They'll benefit from portable work history, and you'll benefit from automatic data transfer when future techs already have profiles.

faq4.question: Can techs change their information after connecting?
faq4.answer: Yes. If a tech updates their address or banking details, the changes sync to all connected employers automatically. No more outdated forms in your files.

faq5.question: Is sensitive data secure?
faq5.answer: All financial data (banking, SIN) is encrypted using AES-256-GCM and stored on SOC2 Type II compliant infrastructure. OnRopePro operates in compliance with PIPEDA (Canada) and applicable provincial privacy legislation.

faq6.question: What happens when a tech leaves my company?
faq6.answer: Their Passport (certifications, work history, safety rating) stays with them. Your company retains records of work they completed while connected. Clean separation for both sides.

faq7.question: Can I require techs to use OnRopePro?
faq7.answer: Yes. Many employers will find it valuable to require techs to create Passports as a condition of employment. The tech gets portable work history. You get automatic onboarding. Both sides benefit.

faq8.question: How does this work with existing employees?
faq8.answer: Invite existing employees to create Passports. Once they do, their future work sessions log automatically. Historical data from before they had Passports stays in your existing records.

faq9.question: What does this cost?
faq9.answer: Technician Passports are free for techs. For employers, OnRopePro pricing is $99/month base plus $34.95 per employee. Passports are included, not a separate charge.

faq10.answer: Create an employer account at onrope.pro. Invite your current techs to create Passports. Start experiencing 10-second onboarding with your next hire.

faq2.answer: Buildings have accounts, not building managers. The new manager changes the building password. Access transfers instantly. The former manager is locked out. No vendor coordination required.

faq3.question: Can technicians see each other's pay rates?
faq3.answer: Only if you grant financial permissions, which you control individually per employee. By default, technicians see only their own work records and assigned projects.

faq4.question: How do residents get access to the portal?
faq4.answer: Building codes. The code appears on elevator notices, gets shared by technicians on-site, or sent by property managers. Resident enters the code, creates an account, instant access to their building's portal.

faq5.question: What if a resident accidentally registers for the wrong unit?
faq5.answer: The system prompts: "There's already an account for this unit. Are you a new resident?" If they confirm, access transfers. If they realize the mistake, they go back and enter the correct unit.

faq6.question: Can building managers see financial information?
faq6.answer: No. Building manager accounts have read-only access to project progress, feedback status, and work history. They cannot see rates, costs, or internal financial data.

faq7.question: How does feedback tracking work?
faq7.answer: Every submission timestamps automatically: when it was opened, when it was acknowledged, when it was resolved. The system calculates average response time and generates exportable reports for strata councils or property managers.

faq8.question: Is my company's data separated from other OnRopePro customers?
faq8.answer: Completely. Multi-tenant architecture means your data exists in a separate partition. Every query, every API call filters to your company only. A security issue with another account cannot expose your information.

faq9.question: What permissions are available?
faq9.answer: 44+ individual permissions across categories: financial (rates, costs, margins), operational (projects, scheduling), safety (inspections, documentation), inventory (equipment, consumables), and employee management (hiring, roles).

faq10.question: Can I create custom roles?
faq10.answer: Yes. While the system includes standard roles (Operations Manager, Supervisor, Technician, etc.), you can create custom positions for unique needs like Inventory Manager or Safety Officer, then assign whatever permissions that role requires.

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.subtitle: Common questions about the Project Management module
faq.a1: Technicians log drops completed per elevation at the end of each work session. The system asks for North, East, South, and West counts separately. Progress calculates automatically based on target drops per direction. Visual progress bars show completion by elevation.
faq.q2: Can building managers see everything we see?
faq.a2: Building managers see project progress, schedules, photo galleries, and safety documentation. They don't see internal performance metrics, piece work rates, or employee-specific data you'd rather keep private.
faq.q3: What happens if we work on all four elevations simultaneously?
faq.a3: Each technician logs drops for whichever elevation they worked. If Tommy worked North and Sarah worked East, their sessions record to their respective elevations. Total project progress combines all four automatically.
faq.q4: Can we use our own job types?
faq.a4: Yes. Create custom job types with your own names and tracking methods. Choose drop-based, hours-based, or unit-based tracking. Custom types save permanently and become available for all future projects.
faq.q5: How does piece work pay calculate?
faq.a5: Enable piece work mode on drop-based projects. Set the rate per drop. When a technician logs 20 drops at $8 per drop, the system calculates $160 for that session. The payroll module pulls this automatically. Technicians see exactly how their pay was calculated.
faq.q6: What if a project gets delayed by weather?
faq.a6: Put the project on hold with one click. Calendar entries update automatically. When weather clears, reactivate the project and adjust dates. Building manager portal shows the updated schedule. No need to send multiple update emails.
faq.q7: Can technicians see their performance compared to others?
faq.a7: Technicians see their own performance metrics and trends. They don't see other technicians' data. Owners and supervisors see company-wide performance comparisons to identify coaching opportunities.
faq.q8: How do I know if a project is falling behind?
faq.a8: The dashboard shows expected completion versus current pace. If a project is behind target, visual indicators flag it before clients notice. You can adjust crew assignments or extend timelines proactively.
faq.a9: Completed projects archive automatically but remain searchable. Historical data powers accurate future quoting. Building managers can still access project records for compliance verification. Nothing gets deleted unless you explicitly choose to.
faq.q10: Does the calendar sync with Google Calendar or Outlook?
faq.a10: The OnRopePro calendar is the source of truth. We're evaluating external calendar sync for future development. For now, the system ensures all internal stakeholders see the same schedule without needing external tools.

faqs.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faqs.subtitle: Common questions about scheduling and calendar functionality.

q1.question: Can technicians see their own schedule?
q1.answer: Yes, if you enable the permission. Company owners control whether technicians can view their own upcoming assignments. You can also enable viewing the full team schedule for supervisors and managers.

q2.question: What happens if I try to assign someone who's on vacation?
q2.answer: The system displays a conflict warning showing the approved time-off dates. You see the warning before the assignment is created. You can override if necessary, but you cannot accidentally schedule someone during approved vacation.

q3.question: Can I still make scheduling decisions if there's a conflict?
q3.answer: Yes. Conflict warnings display details and give you the option to proceed or cancel. The system prevents accidents, not decisions. You remain in control.

q4.question: How does the calendar connect to projects?
q4.answer: When you create a project with date range and assigned employees, calendar entries generate automatically. Change the project dates and the calendar updates. One system, one truth.

q5.question: What time-off types are supported?
q5.answer: 10 leave types: vacation, sick leave, personal leave, bereavement, jury duty, medical leave, family emergency, unpaid leave, training/development, and military leave. Each displays distinctly on the calendar.

q6.question: Can I see both projects and employees in one view?
q6.answer: The dual calendar system provides two complementary views. Project Calendar shows all jobs on a timeline. Resource Timeline shows employee workloads by row. Use both together for complete visibility.

q7.question: How does drag-and-drop work?
q7.answer: Select an employee from the panel. Drag onto the project calendar at the desired date. System highlights valid drop zones. Confirm date range in the popup. Assignment created with automatic conflict checking.

q8.question: What if someone calls in sick last minute?
q8.answer: You can update their status to sick leave for the current day. The Resource Timeline immediately shows them as unavailable. You can then see who's available to cover based on their current assignments.

q9.question: Is there mobile access for viewing schedules?
q9.answer: Yes. The schedule is viewable through the mobile app. Technicians with schedule visibility permissions can check their assignments from their phone.

bm1.example: Vendor explains "the quote only covered the north towers." Nothing in the quote specified which buildings. Your fault for not asking. Their fault for not clarifying. Everyone frustrated.
bm1.solution: OnRopePro quotes break down work by specific towers. Quote shows Tower A: 80 drops, Tower B: 95 drops, Tower C: 75 drops, Tower D: 90 drops. Total drop count listed. Each elevation itemized.
bm1.benefit: Before approving, you verify all buildings are included in scope. No surprises on work day about what is covered versus what costs extra.

bm2.trigger: "Vendor quoted my building last year but I can't find the email to reference the scope."
bm2.pain: Planning this year's window cleaning. Last year's vendor did good work. You want the same scope and service. Email search for last year's quote returns seventeen unrelated messages.
bm2.example: Eventually find it attached to a forwarded message in a thread about a different building. Quote shows a single price. No breakdown of what was actually included.
bm2.solution: OnRopePro vendors' historical quotes stay in the system with building association. Next year, vendor references last year's quote. Sees same drop counts, same elevations, same service breakdown.
bm2.benefit: Compare quotes year-over-year to verify scope consistency. Historical data accessible without email archaeology.

pm1.trigger: "I can't justify vendor selection to the board because quotes don't show enough detail."
pm1.pain: Board meeting agenda: approve window cleaning contract. You selected Vendor B at $8,400 over Vendor A at $7,200. Board member asks "why are we paying $1,200 more?"
pm1.example: Vendor B's quote says "Window cleaning - $8,400." Vendor A's quote says "Window cleaning - $7,200." You explain "Vendor B is more professional" but have zero documentation supporting that statement.
pm1.solution: OnRopePro quotes provide itemized scope justifying price differences. Vendor B quote shows 340 total drops across four elevations, 8-day timeline, includes parkade pressure washing.
pm1.benefit: Board member reviews detailed breakdown. Vendor B approval becomes defensible decision based on documented scope rather than "they seemed good."

faq1.question: Can technicians really not see my pricing?
faq1.answer: Correct. Financial Access permission controls pricing visibility at the field level. Technicians without this permission see the building data entry form without any pricing fields appearing. They cannot see rates, totals, or historical pricing data.

faq2.question: What happens when a technician creates a quote but can't add pricing?
faq2.answer: They complete the site assessment portion - building address, drop counts per elevation, photos, service selections. Quote saves as Draft. You or authorized personnel then open the quote, add pricing using your configured rates, and move to Submitted stage.

faq3.question: How do the pricing formulas work for different services?
faq3.answer: Each service type has its own calculation logic. Window cleaning: drops divided by daily target multiplied by hours per day multiplied by hourly rate. Parkade: stall count multiplied by per-stall rate. Custom services allow manual hour entry. Formulas match how you actually price jobs.

faq4.question: Can I quote multiple buildings in one quote?
faq4.answer: Yes. Multi-building support handles complexes with Tower A, Tower B, Tower C configurations. Each tower has separate floor counts, drop counts, and calculations. Total quote combines all towers. When converted to project, work sessions let technicians select which tower they are working on. Resident portal shows tower-specific updates.

faq5.question: Do quotes automatically email to clients?
faq5.answer: Currently no. Quote PDFs download to your device, then you email from your own email address. Future update will enable direct sending from vendor@yourcompany.com with proper DNS configuration. Download approach ensures quotes come from your recognized email address.

faq6.question: What if my pricing model does not match the built-in formulas?
faq6.answer: Custom service type allows completely configurable pricing. Define your own calculation variables, labor multipliers, and service fee structures. If you need a specific formula added as a standard service type, contact support. Formula requests from multiple vendors get prioritized for system-wide implementation.

faq7.question: How does tax calculation work?
faq7.answer: Tax configuration will be based on building address (province/state determines rate). System calculates applicable taxes automatically. Currently being implemented. You can enter taxes manually in the interim. Future update will support dual-tax jurisdictions (GST + PST scenarios) with override capabilities for edge cases.

faq8.question: Can I edit quotes after they are in "Submitted" or "Under Review"?
faq8.answer: Yes. Drag quote back to Draft stage, make edits, then move forward again. Edit history tracks changes for internal audit trail. Property manager only sees current version. You cannot edit quotes in Won stage (convert to project instead). Lost quotes archive for historical reference.

faq9.question: What permissions do operations managers need to create quotes?
faq9.answer: Create Quotes permission enables quote creation. Financial Access permission determines if they see pricing fields. You can grant quote creation without financial visibility. They assess buildings, create scopes, move quotes through pipeline. You review and add final pricing before client delivery.

faq10.question: How do quotes convert to projects?
faq10.answer: Won quote stage includes "Convert to Project" button. Click button. System creates new project with building address, service details, budget hours, client contacts, tower configurations, pricing data. Quote remains in Won stage for reference. Project links back to original quote for historical context.

faq11.question: Can I track win/loss reasons for pipeline analytics?
faq11.answer: Yes. When marking quote as Lost, you categorize reason (price too high, chose competitor, timeline did not work, etc.). Analytics track loss reasons over time. Identify patterns like "losing 60% of quotes to faster competitors" or "price objections on parkade services." Data informs pricing strategy and process improvements.

faq12.question: Do building photos increase quote file size?
faq12.answer: Photos compress automatically for system storage. Original quality preserved for reference viewing. Quote PDFs include photos at print-appropriate resolution without creating massive file sizes. Download speeds stay fast even with multiple elevation photos attached.

faq13.question: What happens if property manager requests changes to accepted quote?
faq13.answer: Depends on change scope. Minor adjustments (different dates, tower sequence) you can note in project details. Significant changes (added buildings, different services) create new quote version as change order. Original quote stays in Won stage. New quote references original for audit trail.

faq14.question: Can I duplicate quotes for similar buildings?
faq14.answer: Yes. "Duplicate Quote" function copies building template with service selections and configurations. You update building-specific details (address, drop counts, elevations). Pricing models stay identical. Useful for annual renewals or similar complexes in same area. Saves 80% of quote setup time.

faq15.question: How long does pipeline data persist?
faq15.answer: Forever. Won and Lost quotes archive with full historical data. Reference last year's pricing when client requests renewal. Track win rates over multi-year periods. Building associations preserve maintenance history across ownership changes. Data belongs to your company permanently.

faqs.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faqs.subtitle: Common questions about the Resident Portal.

q1.question: Can residents see other residents' complaints?
q1.answer: No. Residents can only view and interact with their own feedback submissions. Privacy is protected by design.

q2.question: What happens when a resident moves to a different building?
q2.answer: They update their Strata/LMS number in their profile and enter the new vendor's code. Their account is fully portable. If the new building's vendor uses OnRopePro, they see that vendor's projects. If not, they notice the gap.

q3.question: Can residents reopen closed feedback?
q3.answer: No. Only company staff can reopen closed feedback. If a resident believes the issue persists, they contact their property manager or building manager directly. This prevents endless back-and-forth on resolved issues.

q4.question: Can property managers respond to resident feedback?
q4.answer: No. Property managers can view all feedback and communication history but cannot respond. Only company staff communicate with residents through the system. This keeps property managers informed without requiring their involvement.

q5.question: What's the difference between internal notes and visible replies?
q5.answer: Internal notes are private (staff only) for coordination, investigation findings, and sensitive discussions. Visible replies are seen by the resident for acknowledgment, status updates, and resolution communication. Staff must explicitly toggle a yellow/red checkbox to make a reply visible, preventing accidental exposure.

q6.question: How do residents get the vendor code?
q6.answer: The code is posted on notices in the elevator during projects, provided by the building manager, or included in project communications. One code per company, used for all buildings that company services.

q7.question: Is there one code per building or one code per company?
q7.answer: One code per company. All residents across all buildings serviced by that company use the same vendor code. The Strata/LMS number differentiates which building's projects they see.

q8.question: How long do residents have to submit feedback after a project completes?
q8.answer: 5 business days. This allows time for residents to notice issues while limiting the complaint window to a reasonable period.

q9.question: What happens if feedback sits unread?
q9.answer: Notification badges show pending items in your dashboard. The "Viewed" timestamp is visible to the resident, so they know if no one has opened their feedback. This creates natural accountability.

q10.question: Do residents see when we add internal notes?
q10.answer: No. Internal notes are completely invisible to residents. They only see visible replies and status changes.

problem.title: The Problem With Safety Theater
problem.scenario: "We're safe" isn't evidence. It's a claim.
problem.intro: Every rope access company says they prioritize safety. Property managers hear the same pitch from every contractor. Technicians can't verify employer claims before accepting jobs. And when something goes wrong, "we thought we were safe" doesn't hold up in court.
problem.howDifferent: How is any of this different from what your competitors say?
problem.solution: The Company Safety Rating changes this. Instead of promises, you have a percentage. Instead of assumptions, you have documented compliance. Instead of hoping your safety culture is strong, you can measure it.

features.title: How The CSR Works
features.subtitle: The CSR uses a penalty-based scoring system. You start at 100% and lose points for gaps in four categories.

baseline.title: Company Document Baseline
baseline.description: Upload your Certificate of Insurance, Health & Safety Manual, and Company Policy to establish your baseline. Missing or expired documents trigger immediate penalties.

projectDocs.title: Project Documents Penalty
projectDocs.description: Each project requires four safety documents: Anchor Inspection, Rope Access Plan, Toolbox Meeting, and FLHA. Missing documents on any project reduce your score proportionally.

harness.title: Harness Inspection Penalty
harness.description: Technicians must complete harness inspections before work sessions. The penalty is calculated as percentage of missed inspections against total work sessions over time.

acknowledgment.title: Employee Document Acknowledgment
acknowledgment.description: When you add Safe Work Procedures or Practices, your score decreases until employees sign. This ensures documents are actually reviewed, not just uploaded.

stakeholders.title: Who Benefits From The CSR
stakeholders.subtitle: Every stakeholder in the rope access ecosystem gains from measurable safety compliance.

employers.benefit3Title: Demonstrate due diligence in liability situations.

faqs.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faqs.subtitle: Everything you need to know about the Company Safety Rating.
faqs.q1: How is the starting score calculated?
faqs.a1: New companies start at 75%. Upload your Certificate of Insurance, Health & Safety Manual, and Company Policy to reach 100%. From there, penalties are applied based on ongoing compliance gaps.
faqs.q2: What if I add Safe Work Procedures and my score drops?
faqs.a2: This is intentional. When you add new safety documents, your score temporarily decreases until employees review and sign them. This ensures documents aren't just uploaded and forgotten. Once all employees acknowledge the new procedures, your score returns to full compliance.
faqs.q3: How do harness inspection penalties work?
faqs.a3: The penalty is calculated as a percentage of missed inspections against total work sessions. If you have 1,000 work sessions and miss 10 inspections, that's a 1% penalty. If you're just starting and have 10 sessions with 5 missed inspections, that's a 50% penalty in this category. Consistent compliance over time builds a resilient score.
faqs.q4: Can technicians see my CSR before accepting job offers?
faqs.a4: Yes. Technicians evaluating potential employers can see company CSR ratings. This allows them to make informed decisions about safety before committing to a position.
faqs.a5: Property managers see your overall CSR percentage and a color-coded badge (green, yellow, orange, or red) through their vendor dashboard. They can also see category breakdowns but not your internal operational details.
faqs.a6: Building managers and residents. Building managers handle on-site logistics (keys, water, parking) and don't make vendor selection decisions. Residents seeing safety scores would generate unnecessary concerns without appropriate context.
faqs.q7: What documents are required for each project?
faqs.a7: Four documents: Anchor Inspection (waived for non-rope jobs like parkade pressure washing), Rope Access Plan, Toolbox Meeting, and FLHA. Missing any of these for a project contributes to your project documents penalty.
faqs.q8: Can my score ever reach 100% again after adding employees or documents?
faqs.a8: Yes. 100% is achievable when all company documents are current, all projects have complete documentation, all work sessions have associated harness inspections, and all employees have signed all required documents. The system is designed so perfect scores are difficult to maintain long-term, reflecting that nobody is 100% safe forever.
faqs.q9: How quickly does the score update?
faqs.a9: Real-time. When a technician completes a harness inspection, when an employee signs a document, when a toolbox meeting is logged, the score recalculates immediately.
faqs.q10: What if a new employee joins and hasn't signed anything yet?
faqs.a10: Your score will decrease proportionally until they complete onboarding documentation. This incentivizes prompt completion of new employee safety training and document acknowledgments.
faqs.q11: Can I export CSR data for insurance or regulatory purposes?
faqs.a11: Yes. Generate PDF reports showing employee signatures with timestamps for all safety documents, harness inspection completion records, and toolbox meeting logs. These exports satisfy insurance auditors, WorkSafe inspectors, and IRATA/SPRAT compliance requirements.
faqs.q12: Is the CSR visible to competitors?
faqs.a12: No. Only your own company owners, your technicians (when evaluating job offers), and property managers (when viewing their vendor list) can see your score. Competitors cannot access your CSR.

faqs.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faqs.subtitle: Common questions about the Resident Portal.

q1.question: Can residents see other residents' complaints?
q1.answer: No. Residents can only view and interact with their own feedback submissions. Privacy is protected by design.

q2.question: What happens when a resident moves to a different building?
q2.answer: They update their Strata/LMS number in their profile and enter the new vendor's code. Their account is fully portable. If the new building's vendor uses OnRopePro, they see that vendor's projects. If not, they notice the gap.

q3.question: Can residents reopen closed feedback?
q3.answer: No. Only company staff can reopen closed feedback. If a resident believes the issue persists, they contact their property manager or building manager directly. This prevents endless back-and-forth on resolved issues.

q4.question: Can property managers respond to resident feedback?
q4.answer: No. Property managers can view all feedback and communication history but cannot respond. Only company staff communicate with residents through the system. This keeps property managers informed without requiring their involvement.

q5.question: What's the difference between internal notes and visible replies?
q5.answer: Internal notes are private (staff only) for coordination, investigation findings, and sensitive discussions. Visible replies are seen by the resident for acknowledgment, status updates, and resolution communication. Staff must explicitly toggle a yellow/red checkbox to make a reply visible, preventing accidental exposure.

q6.question: How do residents get the vendor code?
q6.answer: The code is posted on notices in the elevator during projects, provided by the building manager, or included in project communications. One code per company, used for all buildings that company services.

q7.question: Is there one code per building or one code per company?
q7.answer: One code per company. All residents across all buildings serviced by that company use the same vendor code. The Strata/LMS number differentiates which building's projects they see.

q8.question: How long do residents have to submit feedback after a project completes?
q8.answer: 5 business days. This allows time for residents to notice issues while limiting the complaint window to a reasonable period.

q9.question: What happens if feedback sits unread?
q9.answer: Notification badges show pending items in your dashboard. The "Viewed" timestamp is visible to the resident, so they know if no one has opened their feedback. This creates natural accountability.

q10.question: Do residents see when we add internal notes?
q10.answer: No. Internal notes are completely invisible to residents. They only see visible replies and status changes.

faq1.question: Does OnRopePro calculate my taxes and deductions?
faq1.answer: No. OnRopePro prepares payroll-ready timesheet data for export. Actual payroll calculations (CPP, EI, tax withholding, Social Security, Medicare) happen in your payroll processing software (QuickBooks, ADP, Gusto, etc.). OnRopePro handles time aggregation and export, not tax compliance.

faq2.question: What pay period options are available?
faq2.answer: Weekly, bi-weekly, semi-monthly, and monthly. The system generates period boundaries automatically based on your selection.

faq3.question: How does overtime calculation work?
faq3.answer: You configure the rules: daily trigger (default 8 hours), weekly trigger (default 40 hours), and multiplier (1.5x, 2x, etc.). The system applies these rules automatically to every work session. You can disable overtime entirely if your pay structure doesn't include it.

faq4.question: What format does the export use?
faq4.answer: CSV for payroll software import. PDF for printable timesheet records. Both include employee-level detail and project attribution.

faq5.question: Who can see payroll data?
faq5.answer: Users with the canAccessFinancials permission. This is granted through the role-based permission system. Technicians see their own hours but not compensation rates or other employees' data.

faq6.question: What happens if a work session is missing or incorrect?
faq6.answer: Supervisors with appropriate permissions can review and adjust work sessions before timesheet approval. All adjustments are logged with reasons for audit purposes.

faq7.question: Can I see historical pay periods?
faq7.answer: Yes. Previous pay periods remain accessible. Filter by date range to pull data from any past period.

faq8.question: Does project attribution work if a technician works at multiple buildings in one day?
faq8.answer: Yes. Each work session links to a specific project. If a technician clocks into Building A for 4 hours, then Building B for 4 hours, both sessions show separately with their respective project attribution.

faq9.question: What about non-billable time like travel between sites?
faq9.answer: Non-billable work sessions track hours that cannot be charged to clients (travel, training, equipment maintenance, weather delays). The payroll view shows both billable and non-billable hours so you know your true labor cost.

faq10.question: Is there an approval workflow before export?
faq10.answer: Yes. Timesheets can be reviewed and approved before export. Approved timesheets generate clean export files. The workflow prevents exporting data that hasn't been verified.

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.q1: Is the tech account really free?
faq.a1: Yes. Free forever. No credit card required. No time limits. No feature restrictions that suddenly lock you out.
faq.q2: What if my employer doesn't use OnRopePro?
faq.a2Intro: Your account still works. You can:
faq.a2List2: Import your existing logbook via photo
faq.a2Conclusion: What you won't get is automatic hour tracking-that only works when your employer is also on the platform. But here's the thing: when your employer joins, your account instantly upgrades. All that manual logging becomes automatic. Tell your boss.
faq.q3: How do I import my existing logbook?
faq.a3: Open the app, photograph your logbook pages, and the app reads your handwriting and extracts the data. Review, confirm, done. Years of historical hours imported in minutes-no manual data entry.
faq.q4: Does this replace my IRATA/SPRAT logbook?
faq.a4: No. You still need your physical logbook. IRATA and SPRAT require it. Your assessor will check it. OnRopePro is a digital assistant that captures accurate data so you can fill your physical logbook correctly-not a replacement for it.
faq.q5: What's the difference between automatic and manual logging?
faq.a5ManualText: You enter hours, buildings, and tasks yourself (or photograph your logbook to import). Works anytime, with or without an employer on the platform.
faq.a5AutoText: When your employer uses OnRopePro, your hours log automatically when you clock in/out. Building, height, tasks, duration-all captured without you entering anything. This is the real time-saver.
faq.q6: What happens to my data if I leave a company?
faq.a6: Your profile (certifications, work history, safety rating) stays with you permanently. Company-specific data (assigned gear, company documents) stays with that employer. Your core identity is always yours.
faq.a7: Refer one other technician who creates an account. You both get upgraded to PLUS automatically. No payment required.
faq.a8: AES-256-GCM encryption for all sensitive data. SOC2 Type II compliant infrastructure. PIPEDA compliant (Canada). Your SIN is completely optional.
faq.q9: Can employers see that I'm looking for other work?

features.title: Out of the Complaint Loop. Into the Know.

directComplaints.p1: When your vendors use OnRopePro, residents get access to a Resident Portal. They submit complaints with photos directly to the maintenance company. The vendor responds. The issue gets resolved.

safetyRatings.title: Vendor Safety Ratings: Know Before Something Goes Wrong

safetyRatings.p2: You see exactly where each vendor stands. No guessing. No asking for reports they can fabricate.
safetyRatings.p3: When an insurance adjuster asks "What did you know about this vendor's safety practices?", you have an answer.

vendorDashboard.title: All Your Vendors. One Dashboard.
vendorDashboard.p1: Managing 20 buildings with different contractors? Finding which company services which building shouldn't require digging through emails and contracts.
vendorDashboard.p2: The My Vendors Dashboard shows every contracted rope access company, their safety scores, their response times, and which of your buildings they service. Thirty seconds instead of twenty minutes.

feedbackHistory.title: Feedback History Per Building
feedbackHistory.p1: That resident who complained about streaky windows three times? Track the entire conversation. See when the vendor responded, what they said, how long resolution took.
feedbackHistory.p2: Building-by-building complaint and resolution history gives you documentation when performance conversations get difficult. Or when you're deciding whether to renew a contract.

anchorInspection.title: Anchor Inspection Certificate Upload
anchorInspection.p1: Annual anchor inspections are required for rope access work. You receive the certificate from the third-party inspector. Now you have one place to store it.
anchorInspection.p2: Upload anchor inspection certificates directly to each building record. Your only write permission. Everything else is read-only for data integrity.

accountability.p2: The vendor who takes 12 days to respond to complaints knows you can see that. The vendor who resolves issues in 48 hours knows you can see that too.

faq1.question: How do I get the vendor code?
faq1.answer: Contact your building manager or property manager. They receive the vendor code from the service company and share it with residents.

faq2.question: Can I access the portal from my phone?
faq2.answer: Yes. The portal works on any device with internet access: phone, tablet, or computer.

faq3.question: What if I move to a different unit in the same building?
faq3.answer: Update your unit number in your account settings. Your strata plan number stays the same.

faq4.question: What if I move to a different building?
faq4.answer: Update both your strata plan number and unit number. Enter the new vendor's code when you receive it from your new building manager.

faq5.question: Can other residents see my feedback?
faq5.answer: No. You can only see feedback you submitted. Building managers and the service company can see all feedback for the building, but other residents cannot.

faq6.question: What happens if my feedback is closed but the issue persists?
faq6.answer: Only the company can reopen closed feedback. If you believe an issue wasn't fully resolved, contact your building manager or property manager with documented proof from the portal.

faq7.question: Can I submit positive feedback?
faq7.answer: Absolutely. The system accepts all types of input: concerns, compliments, questions, and suggestions.

faq8.question: How long do I have to submit feedback after work is done?
faq8.answer: Residents have 5 business days after project completion to submit feedback. This window allows time to notice issues while keeping the complaint period reasonable.

faq9.question: Is my data secure?
faq9.answer: Yes. Your account uses encrypted passwords and secure sessions. Your feedback is private and visible only to you and authorized personnel.

problem.title: Safety Theater vs. Safety Culture
problem.intro: Most rope access companies talk about safety. Some have binders full of procedures sitting in the office. A few actually follow them.
problem.p1: The problem is nobody can tell the difference. A technician interviewing at two companies hears the same pitch: "We take safety seriously." One company does daily harness inspections, holds real toolbox meetings, and makes sure everyone understands the procedures. The other company hands you gear and says "don't fall."
problem.p2: A property manager evaluating bids sees the same safety claims in every proposal. Everyone has a "comprehensive safety program." Nobody can prove it. Price becomes the only differentiator.
problem.solution: OnRopePro changes the equation by making safety measurable, portable, and visible. Not safety claims. Safety actions. Documented, timestamped, aggregated into scores that follow technicians and companies everywhere they go.

csr.description: Your company's safety culture, calculated from operational data across four categories.
csr.footer: CSR is visible to property managers. When they compare bids, they're comparing 86% versus 43%. Green badge versus red badge.

flywheel.intro1: Safety has always been theoretical. Companies say the right words. Techs nod along. Nobody measures anything. Nothing changes.
flywheel.intro2: We're making safety practical. Measurable. Tradeable. When a technician's PSR affects their job prospects, they care about their inspections. When a company's CSR affects their contract wins, they invest in their culture. When property managers choose vendors by safety score, the market rewards the right behavior.
flywheel.intro3: This isn't compliance software. This is infrastructure that makes safety worth something. The entire industry rises because the incentives finally align.

newPsr.question: What if I've never used OnRopePro before? Do I start with a zero PSR?
newPsr.answer: New technicians start building their PSR from their first inspection. There's no penalty for being new. Your score reflects your actual history on the platform.

fakeInspection.question: Can I fake a harness inspection just to keep my score up?
fakeInspection.answer: No. The system requires you to step through each equipment category. Failed items automatically retire in inventory. The process takes 30 seconds when done honestly. Gaming it would take longer and create equipment management problems.

psrEmployer.question: What happens to my PSR if my employer has a low CSR?
psrEmployer.answer: Your PSR is independent. It tracks your individual compliance, not your employer's overall score. A disciplined tech working for a disorganized company still builds strong PSR through their own actions.

newCompany.question: We're a new company. Won't we be at a disadvantage with a short history?
newCompany.answer: New companies can reach 100% CSR immediately by uploading core documents and maintaining daily compliance. History matters for weathering occasional lapses, but new companies with disciplined practices quickly build competitive scores.

pmSeePsr.question: Do property managers see individual technician ratings?
pmSeePsr.answer: No. Property managers see company CSR only. Individual PSR is visible to employers during hiring, not to external parties.

disagreeCsr.question: What if I disagree with my CSR calculation?
disagreeCsr.answer: The dashboard shows exactly where you're losing points. If documentation shows 85% but you believe you're at 100%, you can see exactly which documents are missing signatures. The system doesn't hide its logic.

surveillance.question: This seems like surveillance. Is it?
surveillance.answer: It's accountability. The same way a pilot's flight hours and certifications are tracked, your professional safety actions are tracked. This protects you when things go wrong. It builds your reputation when things go right. Your data belongs to you and travels with you.
